Ugh! I really didn't want to go to school today. Well, that was every day actually, but today was different. See, my name's Evan and I'm definitely on the dorkier side of the social spectrum; naturally, this means I'm a prime target for all the teasing, bullying, and hazing of those who are on higher social ground. Oh sure, it's not ALWAYS like that... I mean, I'm not some friendless loser like the Anime Club guys or something. Hell, there's at least a couple of "cooler" people that I talk to. But that's kind of the exception, really, NOT the rule.

But yeah, I'm sort of going off point here. Anyway, back to why I didn't want to go to school. It was just a feeling in the pit of my stomach. A feeling that something bad was about to happen: maybe somebody would call in a REAL bomb threat, or maybe I'd get extra hazing from that jerk Tony Coletta, maybe I'd just fall into a pit... I don't know. All I know is that I definitely didn't want to go to school today.

"Oh suck it up you baby."

I swear, Corinne could be a real pain some times. We got along well most of the time but man, at times she could be extremely irritating. I think she had a bit of an ego or something: "oh Evan, how come you've never had a girlfriend? I mean, I'm a freshman and some of the seniors definitely scope me out!" I mean yeah, she was a nice-looking girl but c'mon. It's teenage guys, you have breasts; you're not special!

"Your sister's right." I glanced up at my mom, not really surprised she took Corinne's side. I'd have to have leprosy before she'd even THINK of keeping me home from school. "You're not sick or anything and you can't stay home because you're feeling mopey."

Gee, thanks mom. Although I can't really blame her. My dad walked out on us about 9 or 10 years back so my mom raised my sister and me by herself. I know she doesn't want us to end up as deadbeats like him.

So I trudged through another boring day of school: made small talk with my buddy Ryan, ogled some of the hotter girls like Stacey Everett, sat through a few boring classes... typical school stuff. And then third period came and that's when IT happened.

Nobody still has a real reason why it happened. I've heard some of the conspiracy nuts on a couple of the message boards I go to say that it was some kind of military experiment that got out of control. Maybe it was, I don't know. I don't even think it matters, really. I mean... like 90-something percent of the world just up and switched bodies, it screwed people up. There were deaths due to accidents of all sorts (although people inflate all that). It wasn't Armageddon or anything, but it WAS a time of great confusion and panic. Even now, things aren't really NORMAL, but everyone's adjusted. I guess it was a little easier than you think, since people tended to mostly switch along age lines and in the same general location. That wasn't always the case though, as I heard a kid in my science class got switched into some old guy who was in the middle of a heart attack; likewise, the football coach got switched into the body of a 13-year-old girl.

There were also the aftershocks: more waves with the same result as the first that came every couple of days for about a week or so. They tended to swap less and less people, though. The first one swapping about 50% and the fourth and final one only being like 1%.

Anyway, my point was that I don't think the cause matters. It happened, what's done is done. Like I said, like 90% or so of the people in the world switched bodies initially. I, of course, wasn't an exception. One minute, I'm listening to Mr. Tomlin give some boring lecture on right angles, the next... well. I definitely wasn't myself, that's for sure...

112.content:
…I was still listening to Mr. Tomlin, but he wasn't lecturing anymore. Instead, he was patting himself in frenzied panic, as if trying to extinguish invisible flames. Most of the rest of the class was staring in shock, but soon the sudden dementia seemed to spread. I'm still not sure why it took me so long to notice what others realized immediately, but for the longest time all I could do was stare in wonderment at the hysteria erupting all around me. I guess sitting in a desk feels pretty much like sitting in a desk no matter who you are, while watching your classmates spontaneously start groping themselves is a little more unusual. Whatever the case, my first clue that something wasn't quite right came from the back corner of the classroom, where Edwin—a gangly, pimply-faced junior who spent most of his time plotting Dungeons and Dragons campaigns during class—was beating the daylights out of the football team's star tight-end.

"Give me back my body you little bastard!" he screamed. "So help me god, I'm going to fucking kill you! You hear me, twerp?"

More specifically, my clue came from who stepped in to stop the fight: me. It was then, watching myself step in and separate the two combatants, that it dawned on me. I finally realized what had come over my classmates, and with sinking horror I looked down at myself, patting my hands frantically across my unfamiliar body just as they had. It didn't take any grand leap of deductive reasoning to figure out whose body I now occupied—there had been only one person in Mr. Tomlin's third-period class wearing a cheerleading uniform: Stacey Everett.

Meanwhile as I continued to fondle myself—more out of confusion than lechery or even simple curiosity—my old body continued to take deceive action. After enlisting the stunned but willing assistance of a couple of other athletes to restrain Edwin, it climbed up onto one of the desks and hammered fiercely on the wall to attract the attention of the class.

"Everyone just shut up and sit down!" my former body shouted. "We all want to find out what the hell just happened here, and we can't do that if we're going for each other's throats. You!"

My old body pointed to me

"Who are you?"

"Uh, Evan," I said.

"Okay, that makes sense. I'm Stacey," said your old body, apparently the real Stacey.

"And you?" she points to Edwin.

"I'm Tony, God dammit!"

"Fine. And you?" she points to Tony's body.

"I'm Edwin," he says. "But I didn't do this, I swear!"

After taking a few more pairs for confirmation, she continues.

"All right, people!" she says in your voice. "Obviously we're way out of our league here. I don't know who—or what—is responsible for this, but the most important thing right now is to stay calm. You're scared, I get it; I'm scared too. But right now we need to find out what's going on, and whether we're in danger. Mr. Tomlin, is there a radio in here?"

"I…I don't know," said Mr. Tomlin. "I'm not really Mr. Tomlin. I'm Becky, from Ms. Fisher's class."

"Fine, so this has clearly affected at least other parts of the school. Our first priority then has to be to figure out just how widespread this thing is. Are we talking about something that just hit the school or is this something bigger? Will hospitals be open? Police? We need to know."

The rest of the class sat silently, listening with rapt attention to the girl in your body. Everyone, that is, Except Tony.

"Oh yeah?" he demanded. "Who put you in charge? You're awfully calm about this—how do we know you're not responsible?"

"Don't be ridiculous," said Stacey. "No one here is capable of something like this."

"Maybe, maybe not," said Tony. "I think we need to reconsider what is and isn't possible, in light of recent developments."

"Look, people! The last thing we need right now is to start fighting over theories and speculation. When we know something, we can act on it. Until then, we need to stick together! Now, who has a working cell phone? We need someone to scout out the rest of the school, see how far this thing has spread."

Nervously, I glanced at the open leather bag beside my seat, and the slim pink phone sitting within. It struck me that Stacey would obviously know about her own phone, but then I'd have been very surprised if anyone in this class didn't have one. What she was really looking for were volunteers.
112.title: Stacey Everett, varsity cheerleader

1121.content:
Now, I'm not exactly the adventurous type by nature. I certainly didn't want to go exploring what essentially amounted to a disaster area just minutes after the most traumatizing event of my life. That said, there was something about the way Stacey was behaving that made me change my mind.. The way she took control, demonstrated leadership in a moment of genuine crisis—all while using my body. It made me realize that I could have done that. That I could have been courageous, could have been the hero—not just now but my whole life. She literally had nothing I didn't have, and look what she was making of it! So I decided to do something courageous myself: I'd go out and scout. After starting to trade phone numbers with Stacey—and then realizing we didn't need to—I exited the math classroom and stepped into the hallway.

Frankly, it was a little disappointing. I'd been half-expecting to step out into fires, rioting and mass anarchy, but the hallway looked for the most part just as it always had. No apocalyptic messages scrawled in blood on the walls, no bands of roving vigilantes wielding shotguns and spiked clubs—just a row of lockers and a drinking fountain. I also didn't exactly feel like much of a heroic explorer myself. As I strode down the hallway, paying as much attention to the unsettling fluttering of my cheerleading skirt, the distracting play of blonde hair across my vision and the boisterous jiggling of certain other bits of my new body as to my surroundings. Despite the gravity of the whole situation, I felt somehow ridiculous walking around even empty halls looking like a cheerleader. Still, my sense of dignity wasn't too great to settle one question that had been the subject of furious debate among my friends.

"Huh." I muttered after twisting everything back into position. "Ryan was right—she is a D cup."

"So?" said Stacey over the cell phone. "What's it like out there?"

"Pretty quiet," I replied. "Not much to see so far."

"Check the other classrooms," she said.

"Empty, so far," I replied. "Looks like everyone cleared out right after the event. They were definitely affected, though. I'm seeing lots of abandoned stuff—backpacks and purses, mostly. It's all pretty neat, though; no obvious destruction I can see. I'm going to check the cafeteria."

First, however, I decided to take a little detour. Popping into the bathroom—the men's, not that it mattered now—I wanted to take a moment to look at myself in the large mirrors. I should have realized, however, that I wouldn't be the only one with this idea. At least twenty other people were already in the bathroom, jostling for position in front of the sinks. The scene here was a lot more like what I'd expected—taps were on, papers and bags were strewn all over the floor, and people were shoving, shouting, and generally on the verge of riot.

"I've found some people," I said into the phone. "They're in the bathrooms. They're practically rioting in here."

"I'll send someone to deal with it. Keep going, get to the administration wing. See if you can find a radio, or someone who knows what's going on. "

"Got it."

By the time I reached the Admin wing, I'd already passed several other groups of people. Mostly small groups—one or two people looking for their friends—but there were a few larger units as well. It seemed the band, of all things, was sticking together and doing their best to break up fights and generally keep order. Meanwhile, someone somewhere had apparently activated the city's emergency warning system, and the sound of klaxons cut through the air—not helping to alleviate the general state of panic one bit.

The office itself was practically empty. The apparent principal was locked in his office watching a small TV, while the rest of the remaining staff were huddled around a bright-orange hand-crank radio.

"…origins of the event are as yet unknown, the Department of Defense has informed us that the phenomenon is not the result of enemy or terrorist action. As of 11:32 a.m., the event has crossed into the Pacific Ocean, leaving only a handful of islands still unaffected. It is projected that the event will reach those remaining locations within the hour, and…"

After a few more minutes of relaying the radio's updates to Stacey, she called me off.

"We've heard enough." She said. "We have bigger issues right now. Edwin's returned with some of the people from the bathroom—there are some injuries. We're going to need first aid supplies. There should be some in the office, but I can send a team to get them. I need you to help with a bigger problem: we need a bigger room. It's getting too crowded in here, and tempers are going to get short fast. We need somewhere else to stay, and quickly."

"Understood. Where should I look?"

"That's up to you. You know better than I do what it's like out there. Use your best judgment, and we'll go where you decide."
1121.title: Volunteer to scout the rest of the school.

"I think I'll check out the cafeteria. That could be a better long term place if we need to feed people."

This was good! You were thinking ahead, planning for the good of the group. You headed across the school to get to the cafeteria.

Along the way, you stop for a drink of water. When you finish, you stand up and reach into your purse for some makeup. You apply lipstick and continue walking.

When you get to the cafeteria, you can see that it won't be an option. There are hordes of people in there, and some fight is going on near the kitchen area. From what you can hear, it sounds like people are rioting for the food.

You push your way in and get jostled around a bit. You hear some shouting and see a disturbance. You can see two people duking it out near the door to the kitchen. If you weren't in the situation you were in, you might have laughed at the scene. Two of Stacey's friends were totally going at it. Actually, it probably was two argumentative guys. Girls wouldn't be that ready for a fight. But now things have taken a turn for the worse. The both of them are looking pretty hurt.

Suddenly, you feel the urge to take action. You stand up on the table and scream as loud as you can, "Listen up! Stop fighting!"

Is it any use?

11212111.content:
Stacey shrugged her broad shoulders. "Grocery store? I suppose any place is better than here. Mr. Tomlin's class was getting out of control; whoever was in Jeanette's body wouldn't stop playing with herself, and it took three people to hold back Gavin French from pummeling her!"

You chuckled nervously. "Good thing you didn't come to the cafeteria. I didn't find any medical supplies there, just two girls fighting and what appeared to be the beginning of a mosh pit enveloping them."

"Seeing you empty handed, I kind of figured the cafeteria was a no-go."

"Hence, the grocery store." You pointed with your thumb and forefinger, both tipped with a cutesy pink polish.

"Okay, let's get in your car and head over there." Stacey proposed, causing you to stop in your tracks behind her.

"I thought you had a car? I was following you, after all..."

Stacey sighed, placing her hands on her hips and striking an exasperated pose. "So neither of us has a car." Before you can reply, she adds, "Wait! There's that pharmacy that just opened over on Waterfront Street."

"Good idea!" You exclaimed. How did you not think of it before? It's only a twenty minute walk from the high school. "If we hurry, there might still be some things we can use. Gauze dressings, penicillin, plasters, painkillers... even a bottle of aspirin would help!"

So the two of you made your way to the local pharmacy. The streets were strikingly quiet, a far cry from the post-apocalyptic landscape you expected to see. No roving bands of armored cars, no pirates wielding golf clubs atop trucks with snow plows attached. Just a handful of people wandering about, keeping to themselves as they stared at their bodies in confusion. Whatever happened to you and Stacey and the rest of the school, confirmed by the radio broadcast, was indeed real. Real and widespread.

Side-stepping a car that had crashed into a wall, you enter the pharmacy behind Stacey. For good measure, she bends down to grab a crutch, wielding it like a weapon just in case anybody got any ideas. Not about her... not the way she looked now as a fairly imposing young man. No. Glancing at the boy wearing her petite body dressed in the cheerleader uniform she threw on this morning, as she loomed over her old body by a full head now. For him. Her. Whatever.

"Don't waste any time on the shelves, all the important stuff is behind the counter." You call out to Stacey, setting down a shopping basket and lifting your butt onto the counter, sliding your legs over and landing on the other side. Straightening out your skirt, you frown. "What I wouldn't give for a pair of sweatpants right now..."

"Just hurry up!" Stacey said. "I think I see someone coming!"

While you begin opening drawers and cabinets, looking for whatever medicines might be helpful in case somebody gets hurt back at the school, Stacey sees an elderly man approach her. He looked to be in his seventies, balding, wearing a white coat and spectacles.

"Just what in the world do you think you're doing, young man?" He screeched, his thick bristly mustache contorting angrily. "I get back from the restroom and the world's gone all topsy-turvey!"

"Stay back sir. I don't want any trouble..." Stacey said, her tone authoritative and commanding with the help of your deeper voice. Brandishing the crutch and studying it on the old man, she asked, "Who are you?"

"Who am I?" The old man shrieked. "I'm Elbert Goodman, I own Goodman's Pharmacy. What are you doing, hoodlum?"

Could this old man not know about people switching bodies? Stacey replied, "You mean... you haven't switched with anyone?"

"Is that what's going on? My med tech Caroline just started raving and acting all crazy, then she left after making a mess over in aisle three. Ruined my uniform, so I went in the back to get changed into this."

He gestured over to one side of the pharmacy. Broken glassware, shelves empty, puddles and packages covering the checkerboard tiling. Stacey lowered her weapon and introduced herself. She took time telling him what she knew while you filled up a second basket with paper bags, pillboxes, an inhaler, even a chilled case of insulin vials... just in case medical supplies become scarce for a few days. Hoping this whole thing would end soon, like a bad dream, and not turn into something longer.

"Hey, what's that girl doing back there? Some people really need that!" Goodman cried, but Stacey held him back calmly. She replied, "I just told you, that 'girl' is really Evan, the owner of this body. And there's a lot more like us over at the high school. We promise to pay for these things later."

"Come on Stacey!" You called out, leaning your back against the emergency exit. "I need your help carrying some of this stuff!"

"Coming!" Stacey leaps over the counter with Goodman in pursuit. He's too old to climb across the counter, and he fumbles with his keys unlocking the door as you and Stacey set off the alarms exiting out the back of the pharmacy.

---


Stacey whooped. "Ha! What a rush! Did you see the look on his face? I thought he was about to call the police!"

You adjust your grip on the basket handles and pant, "Yeah... But if he did call the police, who would answer?" You let Stacey carry most of the weight on the way back to the school. Looking behind you, several other people are fighting in front of the pharmacy. Goodman doesn't seem to be one of them, you sigh gratefully. You met him once before at a parade last year. He's a kind old man whose wife died several years ago and didn't have much awaiting him in retirement, so he decided to start up a local pharmacy for the townspeople. You hope he stays safe amid all of this craziness.

"Hey Stacey, I thought everybody was affected by what just happened? But not Goodman, apparently."

She walked ahead a few steps and stopped. "You're right, Evan. Maybe some people stayed in their original bodies?"

"Any idea why?"

Stacey continued, as you followed behind her. "I don't even know why we switched. Don't get me wrong. You're a nice guy, but we didn't run in the same social circles, y'know? Like, if school was a rain forest we would be on two totally different canopies."

A strange analogy, but she was right. Left unsaid was which of you two occupied the higher social strata. It didn't need to be said.

She turned around with a look of guilt. "I'm sorry, I didn't mean it like that."

"No offense taken," You replied coolly. "Let's change the subject. I could tell you enjoyed using my body to keep that old man under control just now."

Her mood brightened considerably at that. "Gosh, yes! I just felt powerful in a way I've never felt before. So strong, and everything's so much lighter now." She giggled. "But it's a physical kind of strength, y'know? Growing up I was able to command attention by showing off my body. Cheerleading was just a natural fit, come to think of it."

"I was going to say that." You agreed. Stacey's curvaceous body was the subject of every boy's locker room conversation since the dawn of time. Her athletic, toned figure combined with a pair of grapefruit-sized breasts meant she could be the queen bee of the high school if she wanted. Or captain of the cheer squad. Or prom queen. She never wanted that kind of spotlight it seemed. But the ravenous looks of hormone-drenched young men were tossed her way all the same. A fact that the Ashley Smythe's and Trina Peterson's of the world loathed with a passion. This fact you knew only from second-hand sources, whispered through that Amazonian grapevine as it trickled past you on its way down even to the dregs at the Anime Club.

"Taking control in Mr. Tomlin's room earlier this morning... that was pretty inspiring." You admitted to her finally.

Stacey blushed, twirling her short-cropped hair uselessly. "Oh, that? That was just crowd control. You get used to that as a cheerleader."

"Well, I thought it was impressive." You continued, before setting down the baskets momentarily and letting the blood flow back into your rail-thin arms. "I tried to do the same thing in the cafeteria. No luck."

"A lot of it comes down to confidence." She said seriously. "You'd be surprised how people respond to a person who exudes confidence and self respect." Approaching this subject more carefully, she added, "I've seen you get pushed around by Tony Coletta in the hallway a few times. If you stand up for yourself, that asshole will back down. There's a thousand boys like him; the only way for them to feel secure is by making others feel insecure."

You felt your cheeks redden. She was absolutely right, but what the hell? If Ryan said that, you could laugh it off and waste him later playing Modern Warfare. But Stacey, almost a total stranger, sensed what you preferred not to admit even to yourself. Despite being a cheerleader, she seemed remarkably perceptive at reading people.

"D-don't worry about me, Stacey. I can take care of myself." You shoot back in a tone much icier than you intended.

She doesn't say anything, so you walk in silence for a few minutes before returning to the school. What happens next?
11212111.title: How about the pharmacy?

choices: You have better luck finding Ryan.
You go home (or to Stacey's home), with Stacey.
112121111.content:
Returning to the high school, you see conditions largely unchanged. The klaxons were still piercing the cool morning air. A poster announcing the upcoming football game was torn and blackened from a recently extinguished flame. Textbooks and loose leaf paper were littered about the floors. You and Stacey pass a couple boys who were holding each other and crying. An Anime club girl Marie Martin was yanking the hair of Ana Garcia, a sophomore in your Biology class. Stacey separated the two roughly while you sat down on a nearby bench alongside the medical supplies.

Your feet were killing you. Stacey's strappy sandals were not designed for long distance walking, and you could feel a blister on your heel.

"I'm going to find the nurse," Stacey announced, "Hopefully she hasn't switched with anybody and she can help."

"I think I saw her in the counselor's office a moment ago." Ana said, who actually turned out to be Joey Verdugo, a scrappy kid on the freshman baseball team. He massaged his wavy brunette hair and sat down next to you and Marie (actually Ana). This being like the only time the bodies of these three girls would ever be caught sitting together: You, Joey, and Ana.

"So you're really Evan in Stacey's body?" Said Joey, still in shock about the switch. He burst out laughing, "That's awesome! So she like a D cup or a double D? C'mon dude, I gotta know, you know, for science or something!"

Ana cuffed Joey as he yelped out in pain. "Callate, pendejo! Stop making my body sound so estupid." You shrugged your shoulders helplessly at the Hispanic girl currently inhabiting the body of the geeky, stick-thin otaku with dyed blue hair. It was weird hearing Marie talking with a thick accent.

Before long, Stacey returned with Nurse McMillan, remarkably still in her own body. She had been dialing the school superintendent in the counselor's office without success.

"At least someone is thinking proactively around here. Good work, Stacey." She smiled warmly.

"You can thank Evan, he's the one who gathered all that stuff." You feel yourself blushing again, flicking golden blonde bangs out of your eyes and indicating each of the items you borrowed from Goodman's Pharmacy. 'Borrowed' being the operative word... the nurse was glad enough to see someone else acting level headed, she didn't ask questions.

"Mind if I take some of this antiseptic and bandages?" She asked. "The Wilson boy, or whoever is inside his body, fell down the stairs and broke an ankle. I feel like we could use all the supplies we can get." You and Stacey decide to transport all the medicines into her office, as she probably could make better use of it anyhow. A few students help Tommy Wilson hobble into the office, and you could hardly hear anything else above his bawling.

"What should we do now?" Stacey asks you. "This place is close to getting out of control."

Seeing the boy's compound fracture sobered you up quite a bit. Exciting as this might be, safety was still a top concern. What if something happened like that to your younger sister, Corinne? You haven't seen her since this morning, when Mom dropped the two of you off for school. She went to her third period class, Algebra, as you went off to Mr. Tomlin's class before all this happened.

"I need to find my sister, Corinne!" You tell Stacey. Before she can give you your own cell phone, you fish Stacey's pink phone out of her purse and dial Corinne's number. Placing the receiver to your pierced ear, you hear your sister's voice on the other line.

"Corinne, is that you? It's me, Evan."

"Evan? You sound like a girl." She replied.

"Yeah, I've become Stacey Everett. Long story. Are you safe?"

"It's really loud over here. Lots of students panicking. The teacher's out cold."

"Stay on the line, I'll come and get you." You motion for Stacey to follow you. Corinne's Algebra class is on the other end of the school, on the second floor. Your feet still hurt but she's your kid sister. Mom would kill you if you failed to keep her safe in a time like this. Which brings up another unsettling thought: What about Mom? Was she affected?

Stacey wanted to get your attention for a moment. Walking beside her, you place the phone against your chest to muffle the sound.

"Evan, how do you know that's really your sister?"

"What do you mean? You heard her on the line?"

"All I heard was her voice. Anybody could have swapped with her and is using her body right now. Do you have some way to know for sure? Like a test?"

You gulped, a pit forming in your stomach. She made a good point. It was no longer safe to assume the soul matched the body. And estimating how pervasive this mass-switching had affected the school, odds were against anybody claiming they were unaffected. The exceptions, like Goodman and Nurse McMillan, being just that: exceptions.

You place the phone back to your ear. "Sorry Corinne, had to settle a scuffle between a couple of students just now. Are you still in class?"

"Yes, please hurry Evan."

"I'm on my way. I called Mom and she hasn't swapped with anyone, thank God."

"I'm glad to hear that."

"But," You continued, "I haven't heard from Dad since this morning. Last thing he said was he was going to the hardware store to get some irrigation tubing for the backyard. Do you think he's made it home yet?"

A pause on the line. She replied, "Don't worry about it Evan. I'm sure Dad's fine. Knowing Mom, she will let us know when he gets home safely. Are you close yet?"

Click.

You stop in your tracks and hold down your phone. Stacey glances at you with a look of concern.

"That wasn't her, was it?" She mumbled breathlessly.

"No." Was all you said. Corinne would never have said that. Your father has been out of the picture for, what, 10 years now? God knows where he is, probably not a hardware store. Whoever was pretending to be Corinne was doing a decent job, but she (he?) fell into the bear trap you laid for them.

Stacey seemed to realize it without needing to ask. She embraced you in her bigger arms, holding you tightly. "I'm so sorry, Evan. I didn't know..."

You sniffed. Eyes wet. You felt a tear stream down your cheek. Why these tears? You haven't felt anything for the old man in ages. Yet, you just felt like crying. The tension and drama of the day finally caught up to you. Remarkably, Stacey holds you close and rubs your back warmly.

"There, there." She cooed. "Fuck them. We'll find Corinne no matter what it takes."

What happens next?

1121211112111.content:
"Feeling better?" Stacy asks as he sets some microwavable chicken pot pie on the table.

“You can’t be serious.” Gesturing to me, Kelly said, “Like he’s a total loser; he’s nothing like Ashley.”

“For all we know Ashley's dead or missing.” Pausing, Megan said, “Until we find out what happened to her; Evan could totally take her place.”

"You realize what you're suggesting, right?" gesturing to me, Kelly said, "Evan Rogers is like a total loser; it would take a miracle to turn him into Ashley."

"Just think of the anarchy at school if Ashley wasn't around." looking at me, Megan said, "We'll be doing this for the good of the school."

"Okay fine, I'll help turn Evan into Ashley." glaring at me, Kelly said, "You better not mess this up."
11212121112111.title: Angry

112122.content:
I’ll admit to being a little surprised when everyone in the room, including the two cheerleaders, stopped what they were doing. As everyone turned to look at me, I took the opportunity to look around the room. One of the cheerleaders, who I recognized as Olivia Washington, had a pretty nasty nosebleed; while the other one, an unfamiliar girl, had a black eye.

After a moment of no one saying anything, I finally spoke. “This is probably going to sound strange; but I’m not really Stacey Everett, I’m Evan Collins.” Pausing, I said, “A few of us are trying to find a safe place to hide while things calm down; you can stay here if you want, but those who want to come can follow me.”

I could hear murmuring in the room, everyone in here was debating on whether to come with me. Many of them didn’t think it was safe to leave the building, while others thought it best to leave while they still could.

While everyone was making their decision, I got back on the phone with Stacey. “I don’t think the cafeteria is going to work; there’s a few broken windows and some of the doors are busted.”

“We have to find some place safe.” Pausing, Stacey said, “In situations like this, my dad always said it would be smart to find a place as soon as possible.”

I wanted to ask Stacey more about that; when I remembered that her father was a local Police Officer. “You seem to know what you’re doing, Stacey; so I’ll follow you.”

“Edwin said the library looked pretty empty when he was coming back; so I’m thinking we head there.”

It made sense to go there; I knew there were some emergency exits in there if we needed to leave quickly. “I’ll head there with whoever decides to follow me.”

“I’ll see you soon.” Pausing, Stacey said, “Please keep my body safe.”

After putting the phone down, I turned back to the group and said, “Whoever wants to follow me, we’re heading to the library.”
I wasn’t all that surprised when only 6 people decided to follow me. It wasn’t long before we were making our way thru school. We were almost to the stairwell when ______

What happens?
112122.title: The Fighting Stops

1121221.content:
We’d just gotten to the stairwell and we were about to head upstairs when I suddenly felt the ground start shaking. Wondering what was happening, I reached for the railing to support myself when I suddenly blacked out.

When I regained consciousness, I realized I was no longer in the hallway; I was suddenly cowering on the floor of a bathroom stall. Not sure what was going on, I looked down and saw a pair of breasts poking through a cheerleader uniform.

Thinking I must’ve lost track of time and been separated from the group, I stood up. I immediately had trouble maintaining my balance. Looking down, I soon discovered the reason was the pair of knee-length boots I was now wearing. What the hell? I wasn’t wearing those before.

My confusion growing, I opened the stall door and slowly walked over to the sinks. Looking at the reflection in the mirror, I realized I was no longer in Stacey’s body. I was now in the body of Allison Sawyer; another member of the cheer squad and one of the most popular girls in the 10th grade. Why’d I switch bodies again?

Putting aside my confusion, I realized it was a good idea to meet up with Stacey and the others. Retrieving Allison’s purse from the stall, I dug through until I found her cellphone. After taking a few unsteady steps in the boots, I managed to leave the bathroom. Looking around, making sure the coast was clear, I tried to call Stacey but found there was no longer any service.

After getting my bearings, realizing I wasn’t far from the library, I decided to simply head there. It took a few minutes for me to get there but when I did, I saw that the place was empty. Either Stacey never made it, or something had happened.

I started to worry about Stacey; only to stop when I heard glass breaking nearby. It didn’t take much for me to realize that I was in danger. I quickly decided it was best to leave the building; hoping it was safer outside.

As I made my way to the nearest exit, occasionally hiding to avoid people, I started to think about Corinne. She was probably just as confused, and scared, as I was. There wasn’t much I could do to help her now; I had to get myself to safety before worrying about her.

Once I was finally outside the building, I hid behind a dumpster while I thought about my next move. I thought about going to my house but I lived on the other side of town. It was then I saw Allison’s student ID in her purse; with her contact information on the back.

She lived in a neighborhood about 10 minutes from school. It would still be dangerious getting there, but I figured it was closer. With a destination in mind, I started to make my way to Allison's house.
1121221.title: Aftershock

11212211.content:
It took longer than I’d expected to get to Allison’s house. As I walked through the streets, I saw all sorts of chaos; cars on fire, buildings with broken windows and people in various states of shock.

As I walked through it all, I realized that I was in more danger then I’d initially thought – I was in the body of an attractive young girl. Even before all of this, I wasn’t good in a fight; what would stop anyone from trying to harm me now.

Thankfully I made it to Allison’s neighborhood without a problem; the area was in much the same condition as everywhere else. I was walking up the street to Allison’s house when I heard screaming and explosions in the distance. I quickly decided to run the rest of the way, no easy feat in the boots I was currently wearing.

When I got to Allison’s house, I dug through her purse to find her keys. Once I was inside, I made to close and lock the door. With that done, I collapsed against the door and slid down to the floor; crying as the weight of everything finally got to me.

*********************


I stayed like that for almost 20 minutes before I got control of myself. After wiping the tears from my eyes, I stood up and walked further into the house. I was surprised by how nice it was; until I remembered her parents were really successful. They allowed Allison to have parties when they weren’t around; I’d never been invited because I wasn’t a part of the popular crowd.

Walking into the living room, I saw a 70-inch TV attached to the far wall. Ignoring that for a moment, found myself looking at some of the photos on the wall. They were of Allison at various ages; many of them from family vacations.

Seeing some of the places she had been to on vacation, I found myself getting jealous. Allison was a spoiled brat and everyone at school knew it; here she was living the kind of life I wanted but she was taking it for granted.

Walking from the family room to the kitchen, I grabbed a water bottle from the fridge to quench my thirst. I then explored the house some more; eventually coming to Allison’s room. Looking around, I figured this was where her parents spent most of their money; she had a big screen TV on her wall and a closet full of expensive clothes.

Suddenly I started to feel really tired; no doubt from the stressfull experience I’d had today. Walking over to the bed, I took off the boots and laid back. The bed was so comfortable that I was asleep within minutes.
11212211.title: Arriving at Allison's House

112122111.content:
I wasn’t sure how long I’d been asleep; only that a nearby explosion woke me up. I screamed as I sat up in bed, ignoring how girlish my screams sounded now. Getting out of bed, I looked at the clock on Allison’s nightstand and saw that it was only 2:30; I’d slept for about 45 minutes.

Walking over to the window, I looked out and saw smoke in the distance. Seeing the devastation outside, I once again started to worry about Corinne. Retrieving Allison’s phone, I tried to make a call but found the service was still out.

Growing frustrated, I dropped the phone on the floor and walked out of the room. I soon found myself down in the kitchen, feeling rather hungry. Searching through the fridge, I found a Tupperware container full of pasta. After microwaving a bowl, I grabbed a can of soda and went back upstairs.

Sitting on the bed, to no one in particular, I said, “Might as well turn on the TV, see if they’re talking about what happened.”

I went through about a dozen channels until I found one that was on the air. It was the local news station. The news anchor, normally an African American man his 30s, was replaced with a pregnant woman in her 20s. “Authorities are calling this event the Great Shift; following news that as many as 95% of the world’s population has suddenly swapped bodies.” Pausing, the woman said, “As you can see, I’ve been affected as well; having swapped with a pregnant barista at the local coffee shop.”

I started to wonder what could have caused something like this; after a while, I started to worry if it was reversible. Taking a sip of soda, I turned my attention back to the news. “The local government has put a curfew in effect indefinitely. Authorities ask that if you’re...”

The anchor suddenly stopped speaking; as a pained expression appeared on his face. I watched as he looked down at something behind the desk; his face going pale. Trying to regain composure, the anchor said, “I-I apologize for the interruption, folks; i-it seems that my water just broke.”

I spit out a chunk of pasta when I heard that; the former man had just gone into labor. I caught a glimpse of people scrambling behind him; only for the signal to cut out soon after. Staring at the static on the TV for a moment, I eventually turned it off; wondering if the anchor was going to be alright.
112122111.title: Waking Up

1121221111.content:
With the TV off, I tried to find something to pass the time. After a while, I decided to find something to read; except all Allison had in her room were gossip and fashion magazines.

Realizing that I was not going to find anything remotely interesting in Allison’s room, I walked downstairs. I eventually found a recent edition of National Geographic; with nothing else to read, I grabbed that and sat on the couch.

********************


After reading the magazine for a while, I put it down and walked into the kitchen to get something to drink. Walking back to the family room with a can of soda, I found myself looking at some of the family photos on the wall.

The more I looked at them, the angrier I got. All I could think of was how spoiled Allison was and how she had no idea how good she had it. Her parents gave her everything she’d ever wanted, and in turn, she acted like she was the Queen of 10th grade. I couldn’t tell you how many times she would make fun of those of us she thought were losers.

After looking at photos of Allison living it up on expensive vacations, I’d had enough. As I walked back to the couch, a surprising thought came into my head. What if I took Allison’s place?

I realized the absurdity of the idea; I didn’t have a clue how to act like her. Then it hit me, all I had to do was learn enough to fool her friends and family. Over time I could make changes, passing it off as trying to improve myself. Could I really take Allison’s place?

Of course, this whole crazy idea hinged on whether or not Allison came back into the picture. Not only that; but I’d have to be a girl for the rest of my life and I could never reveal the truth to anyone. That last bit gave me pause for a moment; sure my life sucked, but I did love my mom and sister. If I do this, I’m never going to see them again.

As I sat on the couch, I thought about all the positive parts of this idea – I’d be a member of the popular group at school and I’d have parents who’d spoil me. Taking all those points into consideration, I decided to ______.
1121221111.title: Passing the Time

11212211111.content:
Sitting on the couch, weighing all the options, I made my decision – I was going to take over Allison’s life. As I sat on the couch, thinking about what it all meant for me; I was surprised to realize I was more excited by the thought of guys flirting with me. I was now one of the most popular girls in school and I had parents who would give me whatever I wanted.

Getting up from the couch, I made my way to the bathroom. Turning on the lights, I looked at my reflection in the mirror. There were many things to get used to now; including the fact that I was now a girl. As I looked in the mirror, I briefly thought about Corinne and my mom; I would never be able to tell them the truth. "I don't even know what I'm worried about; chances are I'll probably never see them again anyway." Looking at the mirror, I smiled and said, “The only thing I have to worry about now is learning everything I can about my new life."

After spending a few more minutes in the bathroom, I decided to go upstairs to my room. I've got nothing else to do; might as well learn all I can about Allison.
11212211111.title: Take Her Place

112122111111.content: To those of you reading this thread; I hope you enjoy it. I'm open to suggestions/criticism. feel free to contact me
112122111111.title: Note to Readers

1121221111111.content:
It was close to 9:30 before I finally decided to go to bed; I had spent the last few hours going through some of Allison’s diaries to learn about her life. I suppose I should not have been surprised to see many of the entries were about boys at school. It was the same thing with the photos on her phone; typical of a teenage girl, they were mostly selfies of her and her friends.

As I walked into the bathroom, I found myself wondering if I should be exactly like Allison. I’d have to keep up appearances, but I didn’t want to be the kind of girl who was constantly posting selfies to Instagram. I suppose that all comes with being popular; having to document every aspect of my life.

While I brushed my teeth, I could not help but notice my hair kept getting in my face. How does this not drive girls crazy? Once I had finished brushing my teeth, I looked around for a hair tie. It took a few tries but I managed to put my hair in a passable bun. “It’s a start; I’ll just have to practice until I can do it without looking in the mirror.”

Walking back into the bedroom, I pulled the curtains shut. Oncesatisfiedfisfied the house was secure, I went to get into bed. As I lay down, enjoying the comfort of the mattress, I said to myself, “I can definetly get used to this.”
1121221111111.title: Later That Night

11212211111111.content:
It was just after midnight and I had been lying awake in bed for close to 3 hours now. Even after deciding to take over Allison’s life, I could not help but worry about Corinne and my mom. There had to be a way, without revealing that I was really Eric, to reach out to them. Again, none of that mattered if they were dead or somewhere far away.

As if I did not have enough on my plate worrying about my former family, I could not find a comfortable position on Allison’s bed. It was not that the mattress was uncomfortable; it was a very comfortable memory foam mattress. It was my new breasts – I could not, for the life of me, find a comfortable way to sleep without them getting in the way.

After tossing and turning for the last 45 minutes, I finally gave in and sat up in bed. Looking down at my chest, I said, “How can anyone sleep with these things on their chest? They’re like giant balloons.”

Getting an idea, I got out of bed and walked over to the dresser. While she hadn’t developed early like Allison, Corinne’s breasts were almost as big as mine were. I remembered her complaining about them getting in the way when running; until she had gotten a sports bra. Digging through the dresser until I found one, I figured it would help my situation as well.

Holding the bra in my hand, I walked over to the mirror; seeing myself still wearing the cheerleading outfit. I had been hesitant to change out of the uniform; only because, at the time, I had not been ready to see Allison’s body naked. Correction – I had not been ready to see my body naked. I had to get used to thinking of the girl’s body as being mine.

After getting over my initial hesitation, I sucked it up and took my top off; giving myself my first unobstructed view of a girl’s chest.
Of all the ways I imagined this happening, I never imagined the first breasts I saw would be mine.

It took a few moments but I managed to get the old bra off and replace it with the sports bra. After jumping up and down to ensure they didn’t bounce too much, I smiled and said, “That’s much better.”

Before going back to bed, I decided to strip out of the cheerleader skirt as well. Once I was down to only my bra and undies, I climbed back into bed. As I lay down, trying to block out the noises from outside, I once again started thinking about my family. Looks like I will not be getting any sleep tonight.
11212211111111.title: During the Night

112122111111111.content:
I eventually managed to fall asleep around 2AM; only to wake up again at 6:30. Sitting up in the bed, seeing the sun poking through the window, I realized it was pointless to go back to sleep. Getting out of bed, I walked over to the window to look outside.

While I could see smoke and fires in the distance, it seemed that Allison’s neighborhood was relatively untouched; except for a few crashed cars further up the street. Closing the curtains, I walked back over and sat on the edge of the bed. Reaching for the remote, I turned the TV on and decided to see if there was any more news.

Once again the only working channel was the local one from yesterday. I watched as a banner reading MANDATORY CURFEW IN EFFECT scrolled across the bottom of the screen. It wasn’t long before someone appeared on screen; a young boy probably around my age. “If you’re just joining us, my name is Rachel Simmons.” Pausing, Rachel said, “A brief update on events that occurred yesterday; I am happy to report that Kyle Hemsworth gave birth to a healthy baby girl just before midnight last night. Both the baby and mother are fine.”

Sitting on the bed, I found myself thinking about how much things had changed since yesterday; Rachel Simmons had been an attractive meteorologist who I had had a crush on. On top of that Kyle Hemsworth, who'd been on the verge of being a professional basketball player before getting injured, was now a mother. “Seems like everyone’s going to be dealing with changes.”

Turning my attention back to the TV, I watched as Rachel said, “The mayor has instituted a mandatory curfew, effective as of 5 AM this morning, until such time as conditions improve. If you’re in a secure location, it’s advised that you stay there.”

Following that announcement, I turned off the TV. As I sat on the bed, I realized it would probably be a good idea to make sure the house was secure. I wasn’t ready to spend time picking out an outfit, so I quickly put the cheerleader uniform back on. After taking my hair out of the bun, I headed downstairs.

I’d just finished making secure the kitchen and garage were secure, and was making sure the windows were all locked when I heard frantic knocking coming from the front door. Fearing that it was looters trying to break in, I searched for something to defend myself with. After settling on a fireplace poker, I made my way to the front door.

Just as I got to the door, I heard a voice call out, “Ally, are you there? It’s Kelly and Erica!”

Inching towards the door, I was about to look out the window when I heard what sounded like someone putting a key in the door. While Erica and Kelly were Allison’s best friends, I had no way of knowing if it was really them out there.

The door opened before I could find a place to hide; I found myself looking at _____.
112122111111111.title: The Next Morning

1121221111111111.content:
Erica & Kelly walked into the house, still in their cheerleader uniforms. Seeing me holding the poker, Kelly said, “Whoa Ally, it’s us!”

“How do I know that?” looking at them, I said, “How do I know you two weren’t affected by this?”

“We were affected.” Gesturing to Erica, Kelly said, “I’m actually Erica.”

“That still doesn’t prove anything; how do I know you’re really telling the truth.”

“If I wasn’t really Erica, how would I know your dad keeps a spare key taped behind the gutter?”

I had no way of knowing if that was true, but it would explain how they’d unlocked the door. Dropping the poker, I ran over and hugged them. “I’m so glad you guys are alright!”

Looking at me, Kelly said, “Not to nitpick, but how do we know you’re really Allison?”

I couldn’t think of anything to prove I was Allison – because I technically wasn’t. I was starting to panic when something came to mind. Looking at Kelly, I said, “Last week, in the library, you told me how you went to second base with Jake Saunders after the football game.”

That was actually true; I only knew about it because I’d overheard Allison and Kelly talking about it. Looking at me, Kelly said,
“Yeah, it’s definitely you.”

Closing the door, I turned to them and said, “What are you guys doing here? The news said there was a curfew in effect.”

“We were hiding out at school until things died down.” Pausing, Kelly said, “Once we thought it was safe, we snuck out and came here.”

“What happened to you yesterday?” looking at me, Megan said, “The last time we saw you; you were heading to the locker room for gym class.”

I knew I had to come up with a convincing story to tell them. After a moment, I said, “I’d just gotten to the gym when everything went crazy.” Pausing, I said, “I like panicked and before I knew it, I was standing in my driveway.”

“Have you heard from your folks yet?”

It dawned on me that I had not thought about Allison’s parents since this all started. My plan to take over Allison’s life was fine; but not if I ended up as an orphan. “I haven’t heard anything yet, but I’m sure they’ll call when they can.”

“Yeah, I’m sure they’re totally fine.” Looking at me, Megan said, “We haven’t heard anything from our parents either.”

“I’m sure they’re all fine.” Pausing, I said, “They’ll contact us when they can.”

Walking towards the kitchen, Erica said, “Do you have anything to eat? Neither of us has had anything since yesterday.”

“I had some leftover pasta for dinner last night, there should still be some left.”
1121221111111111.title: Erica & Kelly

11212211111111111.content:
Not long after they arrived, I was in the family room with Erica and Kelly; each of us eating a plate of spaghetti. Sitting on the couch, I turned to Kelly and said, "Have you heard about anyone else?"

"Not really; we were basically trying to keep safe." taking a bite, Kelly said, "I did hear something about Olivia Washington ending up in Grace Chin's body. Serves that bitch right; after stealing Tommy from me."

Grace Chin was a pregnant Junior. I had to admit I was glad Olivia had ended up in her body. "Speaking of pregnancies, I was watching the news when I got home yesterday. Kyle Hemsworth, one of the anchors, ended up in a pregnant girl's body and totally went into labor during the broadcast."

After I finished talking, I silently wondered what caused me to say 'totally.' I then remembered how, the night before, I was excited about the idea of guys flirting with me. Was I starting to think like Allison? Looking at no one in particular, Erica said, "There's probably going to be a lot of vacancies on the squad after this."

"Good; maybe now we can get rid of the dead weight." scoffing, Kelly said, "I swear some of the girls just joined the squad to get close to the football team; like that skank Stacey Everett."

I'd heard rumors about Stacey sleeping around, but I never believed them. Before I realized what I was saying, I said, "Stacey's not that bad; I really hope she's alright." Before I could stop myself, I said, "I just hope Stacey's alright; I lost track of her after I ended up in Allison's body."

Looking at me, Kelly said, "What did you just say?"

A lump formed in my throat when I realized what I'd said. With a nervous chuckle, I said, "N-Nothing."

"You're not really Allison, are you." getting up, Erica walked over to me and said, "Who are you."

I quickly realized I was out of options. Looking at them, I said, "I'm Evan Rogers."

1121223.content:
I didn’t surprise me when only 6 people in the cafeteria decided to follow me; given the situation, no one knew where they’d really be safe. We were making our way through the hall towards the nearest stairwell.

We were almost there when I heard a noise coming from a nearby bathroom. Turning to the group, I said, “Keep going to the
library, I’ll be right there.”

“Are you sure it’s a good idea to separate?”

I wasn’t sure who said that until Sophia Richardson, a pregnant Junior, stepped forward. Under the circumstances, I could only assume it wasn’t really her. “Sophia, is that you?”

“No.” shaking her head, she said, “I’m Michael Anderson, I’m an accountant; I work across town.”

“Okay, Michael.” Pausing, I said, “I don’t know if it’s a good idea to separate, but I need to see if there’s something I can do.”

After separating from the group, I walked down the hall. As I headed towards the noise, I started to wonder what came over me just now. Before all this, I wasn’t the kind of person to take charge. Maybe it’s just adrenaline.

Once I was closer to the noise, I realized it was coming from the girl’s room. I hesitated outside the door for a brief moment; until I realized I was in a girl’s body now. Pushing the door open, I realized the sound I’d heard was someone crying. I followed the sound to the stall on the far end and opened the door to find Allison Rogers cowering in the corner.

Allison Rogers was another girl in my class; like Stacey, she was a member of the cheer squad. Kneeling down, I said, “Allison, are you alright?”

Pushing my hand away, she said, “Get away from me!”

“Allison it's me, Evan Stone.” Looking at her, I said, “Are you alright?”

“Ev-Everyone’s gone crazy!” looking at me, she said, “I-I don’t know what's going on!”

Allison was known to be quite mean to those she considered unpopular; I was no exception. But that didn’t mean I wanted her to be in danger. “Allison, get up; we have to get out of here.”

Allison finally came around and grabbed my hand. I was about to help her up when I suddenly felt the ground start to shake.
Wondering what was happening, I leaned against the wall for support when I suddenly blacked out.

I wasn’t sure how long I’d been unconsciousness; but when I woke up, I realized I was ______.
1121223.title: I Heard A Noise

11212231.content:
I wasn’t sure how long I’d been unconsciousness; but when I woke up, it took me a minute to realize something was different. I was sitting on the bathroom floor and still wearing the cheerleader uniform. As I went to stand up, a strand of dark brown hair fell in front of my eyes.

That was my first clue something was different – Stacey had blonde hair. Getting up from the stall floor, I walked over to the mirror and saw Allison’s face looking back at me. Why did I switch bodies again?

Turning around, I was about to ask Allison if she was okay; stopping when I realized that Stacey’s body was no longer in the bathroom. It was probably better that way; she was in hysterics and was not being very helpful.

Feeling the need to call Stacey, I searched for her phone only to find it shattered on the floor. It didn’t take a genius to figure out Allison had broken it when she ran off. Getting an idea, I retrieved Allison’s purse from the stall and dug through it until I found her phone. I immediately tried to dial Stacey only to find there was no longer any service.

“I’m not that far from the library; I should probably just head there.”

Walking out of the bathroom, I headed off towards the stairwell. Once I was on the first floor, I realized just how bad things had gotten. There were desks and chairs strewn all over the hall; there was even the burning hulk of a car smashed into the main entrance. How long was I unconscious?

Spotting a clock on the wall, I noticed it said 1:15 – meaning I had been lying unconscious in the bathroom for the last 2 hours. I heard what sounded like glass breaking nearby and quickly realized the school was no longer safe. Desperate to stay safe, I decided to leave the building.

Once I was finally outside the building, I hid behind a dumpster while I thought about my next move. I thought about going to my house but I lived on the other side of town. It was then I saw Allison’s student ID in her purse; with her contact information on the back.

She lived in a neighborhood about 10 minutes from school. It would still be dangerous getting there, but I figured it was closer. With several choices to choose from, I decided to go to _____.
11212231.title: In Allison's Body

112122311.content:
Allison was known for having parties at her house when her parents weren’t home. I’d never been invited to them because I was considered unpopular. Considering the circumstances, I assumed Allison would fine with me hiding out there until things died down.

As I made my way to her house, I witnessed the destruction and chaos that this Shift had caused. There were burning buildings and cars, and people in various states of panic. Sadly I also encountered a few dead bodies.

It occurred to me, as I was walking, that maybe staying at the school was a safer idea. I was now in the body of an attractive teenage girl; I had no way of knowing if people would try to harm me. Should I go back to school?

I ended up watching about an episode and a half before I got bored with the show and decided to go upstairs to my room and play on my Xbox for a bit. I was doing good, and after a while a couple of my friends joined on with me. I was doing good, with plenty more kills than deaths. But something felt wrong the whole time. Looking outside, i couldn't shake this nagging feeling that I wanted to get out of the house. It was almost like what Stacey had told me earlier, about how she loved to spend time outside. It was as if I had some part of Stacey's subconscious that had now joined my mind.

Eventually, I started getting hungry and decided to tear myself away from my game and head to the kitchen, where I was greeted by Corrine making sandwiches. She must have heard me because no sooner had I walked in the kitchen she turned her head and asked "You want a sandwich Evan?"

"Sure" I replied.

Without a second thought, Corrine grabbed two sandwiches off a stack, put them on a plate and handed them to me. As I accepted the food and took a seat, Corrine asked "hey Evan. Have you noticed yourself acting, different?"

"What do you mean?"

"I mean, are you noticing that your not acting like yourself"

I thought for a moment before telling her "you know, I have noticed that I get these subconscious feeling every now and again"

"Like what"

"Well, earlier Stacey was telling me about how she liked spending time outside, and I keep getting this feeling that I want to spend as much of my free time outside"

"Wow, I almost have the same feeling. Except I keep getting the urge to have a cigarette or take care of everyone. Heck, I've even started feeling uncomfortable wearing what I put on this morning"

As the two of us continued talking, slowly everyone began entering the kitchen one by one as they were getting hungry. They would join the conversation for a bit, before heading off to continue whatever it was they had been doing. From what we could gather Mom, Dad, and Stacey all were noticing the same thing where they were getting subconscious feelings that they know weren't their own. It would be discovered years later that there were small amounts of a persons mind that stayed back with their old body, rather than travel with them. For now, we all just seemed to assume that this was our minds way to try and cope with a change as drastic as what we all went through.

112211111.content:
It's been a couple of days since I found myself in Stacey's body, and I hate to say it by I've started getting used to some of the different feelings. Heck, waking up every morning and seeing Stacey's pretty face looking back at me isn't even surprising anymore. And based on what I've seen from everyone, they've started to feel the same way. And I was starting to get the feeling that I wanted to go outside and do something. Anything really, I didn't care what at this point. I'd actually started getting bored playing on my Xbox. After I went downstairs for some breakfast, I saw Stacey who told me she was feeling the same way. That she also wanted to get out of the house and do something. "Hey, I have an idea" Stacey said in between spoonfuls of cereal.

"What?"

"Why don't we go to my house for the day"

I thought about it for a moment before asking "Why?"

"Well, for one it would be a change of scenery. There's plenty we could do. And we could take some of my clothes back here so you don't have to constantly share with you mom"

"Well, that actually sounds like a good idea"

"What sounds like a good idea?" Mom asked as she came downstairs to join us for breakfast.

"Stacey was just suggesting that since we were both feeling a little stir crazy, we head over to her house and spend some time there"

She was silent as she thought about it. All the negative possibilities of what could happen were certainly running through her mind. Eventually though she allowed us to go, with the condition we would be back by dinner. With that, Stacey and I quickly finished our breakfasts and ran upstairs. As I was about to head into Corrine's room to get some clean clothes, Stacey suggested I go over in the pajamas I was wearing now and change once I get there so there's less I would have to take back.

Once Stacey had finished changing, the two of us went to the garage where we took my mom's SUV and began our drive to Stacey house. I let Stacey drive sense she knew where she lived and would get us there a lot quicker than if I drove. The two of us talked for the whole drive, changing from one topic to another. Eventually though, we arrived at Stacey's house. She lived outside of town in what seemed like the middle of nowhere. After turning off the road we drove down a very long dirt driveway. From the road, you couldn't even tell there was a house here if it wasn't for the break in the trees and mailbox. We then drove what seemed like a solid quarter mile before pulling up to the house. The house itself was a fairly good sized place, apparently 3 stories with a 2 car garage and a good sized pull barn not to far away.

After Stacey parked and we exited the car, she lead me to the house. Using a key hidden by a fake rock, she unlocked the door and walked in with me close behind. Once inside, Stacey showed me to her room so I could change into her clothes. After she left me, I slowly took in all the sights before me. I was in the bedroom of one of the most popular girls in my school. As a whole, it wasn't that dissimilar to my own sisters room. Although there was definitely a country vibe going on. Moving on to the closet, I was similarly surprised with the clothes I found. For as long as I could remember Stacey was always a really nice dresser, often coming to school in whatever was popular for girls. But in her closet I found a large supply of camo and other clothes you'd expect from a person who'd spent their whole life living in the country.

After looking through everything, I settled on a rather simple black bra and pantie set, a pair of looser fitting blue jeans (that were still rather fitting around the hips and butt) that had a rip over the right knee, and a red short sleeve tee shirt with the local colleges logo on it. After getting dressed I slowly walked downstairs, taking in every sight this house had to offer. It took a minute, but I eventually found Stacey. She was outside, currently sitting on a low branch of a tree in the back yard (although she was still about 7 feet or so off the ground). I walked outside to join her, still barefoot. "I never would have pegged you as a country girl" I said as I neared the tree.

"Yeah. Side effect of living out here I guess"

As I started climbing up towards the branch she was sitting on I asked "So, what was first? Country Stacey or girly Stacey?"

Smiling, Stacey replied "County. Definitely country Stacey"

"What sparked the change?"

Stacey was silent for a moment as she recalled her past. I could see a tear forming as she said. "My mom. My mom came back"

"Your mom left you" I asked. "I never knew that"

"Nobody does. You see, early in their senior year of college when my parents were still dating my dad accidentally got my mom pregnant. She freaked out, didn't want to have a baby. But my dad talked her into not getting an abortion. It kinda drove them apart a bit. But 9 months later, she gave birth. One hour later she had signed away all parental rights she had over me. My dad ended up moving in with his older sister for help raising me. Around when I was 2 my dad decided to move out here, which is where I became a country girl. Shortly after the start of 6th grade my mom had a change of heart and wanted to try and be apart of our lives again. She was doing well and felt bad about leaving, so she talked with my dad about coming back. He said he'd give her a chance, and she ended up staying this time"

I stayed as I processed what she told me. "Are your parents still..."

"Separated?" She said finishing my sentence. "No, they're together now. They started dating again freshman year and got married a year later"

We sat without saying a word for a minute, and I could tell talking about her past had brought up some feelings that Stacey had tried to keep buried. She wasn't crying, but tears had begun to form in her eyes. What happened next, neither of us had anticipated. Something came over me as I leaned over and kissed Stacey on the cheek. We were both startled by what I had done, and sat next to each other with saying a word for a few minutes. Eventually, Stacey spoke up and asked that I not tell anyone what she had told me. I, in turn, told her that it wasn't my story to tell.

The two of us spent most of the afternoon doing various chores, mostly cleaning the house because nobody living in the house for the last little bit has left it surprisingly dusty. Around noon or so we fired up Netflix and watched movies for a majority of the afternoon. Eventually though, we noticed that it was starting to get late and knew we needed to head back to my house soon so we ran up to Stacey's room and grabbed a bunch of her clothes and loaded them into the back of my mom's car. After the both of us had ran up and down the stairs several times we had moved about half of Stacey's clothes and felt that was good enough for now.

As we drove back, we talked about how we thought things would be different once things started returning to somewhat normal. I told her that I think that it would be surprising how quickly people start returning to normal. That for the most part nerds will still be nerds, bullies will continue to bully, and so on. Stacey, meanwhile, thought that this will cause people to have more of an understanding about the problems that other people have and that humanity as a whole will be better off because of this. We ended up deciding that on this topic we would have to agree to disagree for now and see who ends up right in the long run. But this didn't keep us from chatting for the remainder of the drive back to my house. We ended up arriving shortly before my mom was pulling dinner out of the oven. She jokingly gave us a hard time about arriving so close to her dinner deadline, but didn't make it a huge problem of it.

Later that night, Stacy told me that I the cheerleading squad was starting up again for the first time since the Shift and she thought I should go out for it. I was actually excited. Cheerleading actually sounded fun to me.

It started with the world turning black-and-white, and then gray-and-white, and finally white-and-brilliantly-blazingly-blindingly-white. Mr. Tomlin's face suddenly looked even more skull-like than usual, but I only had time to wonder (illogically) if I'd suddenly acquired X-ray vision when the wind hit. Softly, but gently, like a very large pillow. But if it was a pillow, it was one swung by an irresistibly strong arm; and I was suddenly as light as down. It lifted me from my chair, and for a moment it seemed as though my stomach would not be joining the rest of my body on this very unexpected journey.

And then ... An eternity later ...

There was a snap and a jolt, and everything was back to normal.

Well, it would have been back to normal, if I were still in Mr. Tomlin's class instead of—

"Mrs. Cunningham?" The voice was very soft, but it rang out like a shout, for no one else in the room had been making a sound. In fact, it had been so silent that only the sudden jolt of that voice made us realize that a profound stillness had been hanging over everything.

My neck felt very stiff, and it seemed to crack when I shifted to look for the speaker. Nia Lewis it was who had raised her hand. Mrs. Cunningham, the history teacher standing at the front of the room, and most of the students, were staring at her in shock.

"Mrs. Cunningham," Nia repeated, and her tone sounded very plaintive. "Should I move back to my seat?"

The teacher looked around, her eyes staring in surprise and horror. I shifted in my desk and looked around uneasily. I wasn't supposed to be in here at all, I was supposed to be in Tomlin's math class, and if Nia thought she needed permission to move back—

Another hand shot up. "Mrs. Cunningham, I'm supposed to be in Coach Willis's algebra class," said Josh Coffman, one of the chess club whizzes, and a kid who had aced the AP Calculus class his junior year.

"I'm supposed to be—" started another voice, and then a sudden babble broke over the whole room. I looked around in confusion. Had everyone gone mad? Or was it just me? Suddenly Nia began to scream. She pointed at Tracy Sandoval, who was two rows over, and covered her mouth with her other hand and let loose a yelp so loud and high-pitched that everyone winced. "Nia!" someone snarled, but she paid no heed, and only kept pointing and screaming.

She was still screaming when a terrific roar and boom broke over the school, and then her screams were quickly swallowed and blended with the agonized screaming of tearing metal.

* * * * *

I didn't find a mirror until well after the change, but there were enough windows in the school—tinted with a reflective material—to settle the question quickly enough. With everyone else I'd risen to my feet and tried stampeding from the room, but even in that panic I'd been briefly transfixed at finding my skin many shades darker than it should have been, and at finding myself unaccountably clad in floppy athletic shorts. I stared and swallowed when I got outside and glanced at a window, tilted just right against the angled sun, and in it recognized Omar Baez's astonished face gazing back.

I stopped and ran my fingers through my hair, and saw the shadow in the window pane do the same. I dropped my hands and looked down at dusky, well-manicured fingers—so much stronger and thicker and better maintained than my own well-bitten digits. Strong forearms, with dark, soft hair, well-tanned even for one of Turco-Persian ancestry. My eyes drifted back up to the window; my mouth (my mouth!) was agape, and even in the dim reflection I could see the strong, white teeth.

"Omar!" Probably it was only because I'd been staring and thinking that name to myself that I turned. A guy—a freshman, by the look of him—I'd never seen before came hurrying up, his face twisted as though trying to hold back tears. He stopped short and stared at me, and I must have stared back. His brow clouded. "You're not Omar, are you?" he said, and his voice cracked. "No one is," he said bitterly before I could answer, and hurried away, his head down.

I'm not Omar, I thought to myself. Except, somehow, I am. Am I? I looked back at the window in a daze, and then turned and followed the rest of the students and teachers, who had begun to stream, and then to run, from the school, and from the stench and rumble of burning jet fuel, and from the thick, oily column of smoke that billowed over the athletic fields.

* * * * *

The street in front of the school was a knotted pile of trucks and cars; most of them abandoned, a few trying to nose their way through. People were wandering through the mess. They'd poured out of cars, poured out of the storefronts on the other side of the street from the school, poured down the street from all other directions and fought each other to pass. The last thing I remembered before everything went black was listening to Mr. Tomlin math lecture. The next thing I know, I am sitting at a table in the library. As I looked around, I realized the entire room was in a panic; with people screaming at each other or cowering under the tables.
